SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A WORK OF EXPLORATION INTO THE PERSON

SHOWING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to measure a general questionnaire on pioneer life because some of the questions have to answer them to satisfy the above requirements. It is impossible for you to answer all of them without having blank spaces. It is not necessary to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not. If more than one member of the family can answer the question, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Picti: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Please send a form to Leslie Brown.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A list of questions is attached to this questionnaire.

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual can be expected to have a complete knowledge of all aspects of pioneer life. It is not necessary to answer every question in detail; however, it is important to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may have personal experiences of the pioneer years which are not included in the questions. If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pictorial History," has been answered by many individuals who have already answered this questionnaire. If you have not already answered this questionnaire, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of its permanent records of the province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

PIONEER EXPERIENCES - A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure who the name is correct or if you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your discretion, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Leslie Brown
2. Your address: 525 Brown (Mr. and Mrs. Leslie)
3. Date: Nov. 9, 1953
4. Where were you born? Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation? William King
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? March 3, 1892
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan.

In 1891 my father was out homesteading near the famous Harvey Flats. We came to Canada in 1892. How did you learn about the West? Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?

Our neighbors in Crest bought a team of horses from my father and said he was going out to homestead on the North West Territory. So the very next year my father went there also. Homesteading at age four months before he left for home in Oct.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought the west was free & wild at first but gradually my father and mother also bought children.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

My family.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We came CPR and had a car to ourselves which took us to a store and we pulled out slat seats to make a bed; we had our bedding with us.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other misfortunes etc.)

My grandfather gave my mother $40 to buy a cow when she got here. If she could get one as he said so many little ones should have milk.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

A uncle met us at Station and we were there a few days! Then father got a vacant lot near farm cottage there after gradual gleed (3 rooms) but built a house on it.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Fat River, need a farm.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

When I married I lived for 4 years on a farm 1/2 mile North of Medicine Head, near Apple Valley on Katepwa dist., the Pasture.

Three years I have been living in Medicine Head.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was a child but my father had a small mill on Crow and out Wheat here. There are also barns the build for was done by O. Howard who was a nice handy man. My father was also Captain very hearty and never idle so he was a very good man.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They really thought the West was free or wild and there was plenty of land.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)?

My father and mother also eight children.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came CPR and had a car to ourselves which had a store and we pulled out slat seats to make a bed, we had our bedding with us. They called it a car when she got here. (If she could get old enough to marry little ones should have a car.)

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement)

My grandfathers gave my mother $40 to buy milk.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

A uncle met us at Station and we were here a few days! Then father got a vacant Bell Farm cottage here at Qu'Appelle Head (3 rooms).

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Qu'Appelle Valley near Qu'Appelle Head

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

When I married I lived for 44 yrs on a farm 1/2 mile north of Qu'Appelle Head, near the Pasture.

Three yrs I have been living near Qu'Appelle Head.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was a child but my father had a good mill in Ont and put Wheat here. There are now mills in Ont and put Wheat here built for man camps. However also Barns so he was a store very handy and never idle so he was a Captain.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

We all three eldest children wrote back faithfully the first two years then about once a year until we needed new friends.

20. If you got married, give the names of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

I have been married three times first to Leopold Brown Dec 14, 1944 (13) 1897 then to

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yea a great many came on harvest season and some went back but most of them stayed and later farmed

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

But right now I have one bro at Powell River BC another in Yassama one in Calgary also one in Saskatoon another in Seattle and two dead one sister in London Ont and one at Woodman Park myself and two dead four of them were from here

23. If there any particular incident of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

My eldest brother fielded up a team of oxen he was 15 yrs old and five of us quit the wagon! The oxen ran away and got into the middle of a big plough and started there, the they had just gone and we all got wet as we had to wade out.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

Yes we went to church also to town which was 1/2 miles on a waggon but we had horses, we all walked to school a distance of 3 miles and took our heels and hid if we ever saw Indians

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

We all three wrote about once a year until we moved.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

I have been married since first to George Brown from 14th June 1897.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, please list them.

Yes, a great many came on harvest work and some went back but most of them stayed, and later farmed.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

But right now I have one brother living in Calgary, one in another in Vancouver, one in Seattle and one at Brandon, one in London Ont., and one in Saskatoon.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to report?

My eldest brother died up a team and oxen he was 15 years old, and five of us went into the wagon. The team ran away and got into the middle of a big slough and stood there, they had just gone and we all got wet as we had to wade out.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Yes, we went to church also to town which was 1/2 miles on a wagon but we had horses, we all walked to school a distance of 3 miles and took our tools and kid if we ever saw Indians.

25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1908

26. If you owned a car before 1914, what did you buy it for? What makes a car worth almost as much as land today?

27. How far from your home was the nearest trading center? How far from your home was the nearest post office?

28. Did you contribute to build schools? (Include any churches or other buildings.)

29. Better means of travel, etc., we had no new facilities.

30. How often did you shop in the early days? About once a week.

31. Then (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

32. Not until after we had cars.

33. Then (if ever) did you start begin to buy through the mail order catalogue? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what proportion of purchases made by mail order were by catalogue.

34. As soon as we got catalogues, we bought all our clothes from Eaton's and Simpson's; we had very cold winters and did not go very far, especially the women folk.

35. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Bell Telephone Co.

36. It was installed in Aug. 1912.

37. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? Then did you make this decision?

38. As children when we left Brandon we all thought we were going back East and we were very happy, but we were turned around and as the saying goes "father know's best."
25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1908.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, then did you buy it? Yes, we did.

27. What was your trading center? Our trading center was in the early days almost over a week every Monday morning.

28. How often did you stop at the early days? Almost every day.

29. Then (in 1914) did people in your district first start going to town regularly?

30. Then (in Saturday) not until after we had cars.

31. Then (in 1914) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue? As soon as we got catalogues, we bought all our own farm potatoes and pumpkins, we had very cold winters and did not go very far, especially the women folk.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1930? If so, why?

No one was able to move, we every one was trying to make a home in the west.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes, a great many went to Ontario and BC, also some headed away north at once was hard times, nd prices for stock or eggs or bacon.

My youngest brother was Postmaster and taught a night school, the nurses to Vernon etc., and carried on store business we have masons and Oddfellows Eastern Stars and I am a Orange Lady

Two men were able to move, one every year. One was trying to make a home in the west.

Yes, a great many went to Ontario and BC, also some traveled away north at our own expense. We had times of plenty and times of want.
